text:
have made this recipe twice and haven't been able to use 4.5 cups flour--more like slightly less than 4.  1st time was with tikka masala and 2nd with gyros.  2nd time around was much better--fluffier and softer (i think that the yeast was fresher and more time was allowed for the rise--even forgot the milk 2nd time).  no leftovers.  used the grill and had excellent results.  we like ours about pita thickness.  found that dividing into 8/9 produced better results than 12.  definately a regular part of the menu. will use more garlic next time and try doing the 1st rise in the breadmaker.

text:
I'm giving stars based on how much I liked it rather than how close it was to restaurant taste since this is the first time I've ever had naan, and I have nothing to compare it to.  The only variation I did was to omit the chopped garlic and instead put a sprinkle of garlic powder in the butter to baste the bread with.  We served it with Chicken Jalfrezi from this site.  My husband thought it was too dry on its own, but enjoyed it as a sauce-soaker-upper.  I pulled mine apart (think pita) and put the meat and sauce inside...very enjoyable, and my son had a blast helping me make it.

text:
This was great! My boyfriend and I loved it...and we are BIG naan fans!!

I live in Japan, so I don't have access to a grill (other than my BBQ and it was too cold to light that up!) so I cooked them in a frypan with some spray oil. It worked just fine and only took about a minute each side. 

We had too much dough for the two of us to eat in one sitting so I split it in two, mixed in some black olives, cheese and parmesan then baked a nice loaf of bread while the curry was cooking!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best naan ever! I didn’t have bread flour so I used white flour and I have no regrets! So if you don’t have bread flour, trust me it will still turn out. Made it on a grill pan. Cook over medium-high heat and you’ll have no problem getting the bubbles to form. I should also  say I made the dough pretty thin before cooking (just used my hands to pat down the dough until it was translucent), which helps creates the bubbles that everyone craves.

Maybe over the summer I’ll try making it on the grill, but for now I’m in love!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been sitting on this recipe forever because I was intimidated by the thought of grilling bread dough. Finally today I tried it on the stovetop, and boy is it ever delicious. I only had 2 cups of bread flour so the rest was all purpose, and I don't think I used the full amount called for. I heated up my cast iron 'pancake pan' really hot and then turned it down to medium low to 'grill' all the naan. For the garlic, instead of kneading it into the dough I melted the butter in a pan and heated up the garlic in it for a bit and it turned out well; subtle garlic flavor with no chunks. I made a huge pile of naan and DBF ate about half, this recipe was a hit!

I have made  this recipe many times. I don't need quite as much flour as the recipe calls for and I add 1 1/2 tsps of garlic powder with the flour instead of minced garlic. I've made this recipe several times, and the only problem I have is that I can hardly keep from eating the whole batch at once! I make these on my grill pan on the stove, and find the trick is to roll/stretch the dough out as thin as possible to get lots of soft yummy bubbles. I fired up the outside grill and grilled the first naan but with the hot Texas temperature in August I just couldn't fathom grilling a dozen of these so I shut it down and grilled them inside on a Lodge cast iron grill skillet. text:
This turned out better than I thought it would. My dough looked like it wasn't going to come together because it was so hard and dry. I had to add some more water to the mixture. Next time I would try not adding as much flour. I also added a half teaspoon of baking powder because I like the bubbles in naan that form when you cook it. I didn't add the garlic to the dough but rather to the melted butter. I also sprinkled it with fresh chopped rosemary. My husband and I loved this. I only made a few for dinner and I have the rest in my freezer for future use. Even though this turned out great, I'm giving this 4 stars because as written, my dough wouldn't have come together.

*Update: just FYI that this dough freezes great! I froze half of the dough in small dough balls and when I was ready to use them I defrosted them on the counter and rolled them out like normal. I also seasoned them any way I wanted and they turn out so good every time!

text:
This was my first attempt at making naan and I'm quite pleased! I followed other reviewers' suggestions and only used about 3 1/2 cups of flour. Made sure to "activate" the yeast by adding 1/2 tsp of sugar to the water and yeast mixture, which worked like a charm (I followed the yeast packet directions and only mixed the yeast with 1/4 cup water to activate, and then added the rest of the required water when mixing all the ingredients together). 

I think the next time I make this, I'll cut down the 1/4 cup sugar to 1 Tbsp - it just seemed far too sweet for naan.

I opted not to knead the garlic into the dough, but rather put it in the butter when I melted it and brushed it on as I cooked the naan. 

I don't have a grill or grill pan, so used my trusty cast iron pan and it did the job! I cooked up half the batch and then had to take a break (WHO CAN NOT GIVE IN TO A BIG PILE OF NAAN STARING AT YOU?), but probably shouldn't have. I think the second half ended up being a bit more tough due to the delay in cooking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM! These were salty, yummy heaven! A few technical errors (I was making these with two over-eager eight year old kids), but all in all a great recipe. Tips: I added 1/2 a teaspoon of baking soda and tried to coax the kids into rolling them as thinly as possible (They failed to do so half the time.) We cooked them in a typical pan, and every time we cooked one I put a dab of butter and put the rolled dough over it. (The more butter, the saltier and bubblier they'll be!) The first time I set the dough in a bowl and covered it, it didn't rise. My problem: Too cool of an environment and I had forgot to transfer it to a plastic bowl! But after (punching and flipping then) putting the dough in a medium sized plastic bowl and covering, it rose within an hour. Also, the second time they rise, try to cook them ASAP. I left mine for a half hour too long, and they got semi-tough on the top. I assume that's why they didn't thin so nicely.
All in all, great recipe and will be used again in the near future! My fam loves them with hummus!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
O. M. G. !!  After trying these, I don't think we like regular home-made bread or rolls anymore!  This recipe is the bomb!  I included the optional garlic.  No changes needed at all.  Recipe, including instructions, is very easy to follow.  6/22/15 update: I made the dough in my bread maker this time, and it came out great (husband said the best yet)!  Added the water, milk, and un-beaten egg to the bread maker first, then the flour (used bread flour) and the rest of the ingredients, except for the garlic and butter. I did have to add a couple extra tablespoons of water to soften the dough because the bread maker was working too hard during mixing. I kneaded the garlic in by hand, on a corn-flour dusted breadboard, after the dough cycle was complete, then formed the balls and followed the remaining steps exactly as described in the recipe.  11/7/2018 update: Made a gluten free version by increasing the yeast to 2.5 Tbs, substituting Pamela’s bread mix for the flour and plain yogurt for the milk.  It was a bit stickier than with wheat flour,  and not as elastic, so it actually rolls out more easily and does not tend to shrink back after rolling like “real” naan does. I floured the breadboard generously with the bread mix while rolling to firm up the dough and prevent sticking, and was able to bake on the grill just like the real naan. It didn’t puff up like the real stuff, but it was still some of the tastiest, chewiest gluten free bread I’ve had. Would make great pizza crust

userID:
10908435
Display Name:
drystoneoven
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0

1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe.  I have not tried this in a grill, but have opted to use the wood fired oven I built after heating it to 900 degrees or so.  They cook pretty quickly at that temp.  I even took a video of cooking two:(http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vfszsfQBlDE


  I added some finely minced onion which enhances the sweetness, and on the second try I substituted homemade kefir for the milk and water.  Adding kefir (or you could do some percentage of yogurt) I think gives it a more authentic taste, which is to say, more like I've had in good Indian restaurants.  

Bottom line is, if you don't add some kind of tangy dairy, I think you'll get naan that is very vanilla and just plain sweet tasting.  Of course, without cooking it at the proper temps, you'll have difficulty creating the chewiness and bubbling that people love about authentic naan.
Review:

4

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very, very good recipe.  I had to omit the egg and I used 1 tablespoon melted butter to replace it for the moisture.  I didn't have bread flour so I used all-purpose flour but decreased the amount to 3 1/2 cups.  I also added 1/2 teaspoon baking soda. 

I hand flattened the dough rather than rolling and cooked in a cast-iron skillet over medium heat.  I covered the pan while they cooked for 3 minutes on the first side.  I then brushed with melted butter with a dash of garlic salt added, flipped them over and then continued to cook for an additional 2 minutes.  

They were delicious!

text:
This is a nice treat and other than the time involved is fairly simple.  If I could I would avoid the sugar, ut it is absolutely necessary for the raising of the dough.  I put 2 cups of water in a glass container into the microwave and heat it for 2 minutes. Leave the water in the oven, turn the microwave off and put the bread inside to "proof".  It stays warm just long enough to do the trick

Wow! This is delicious. I used my bread machine on the dough setting (1.5 hrs) and used 3.5 cups of bread flour. I still proofed the yeast before putting the ingredients in the machine. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/395990.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love it! Used instant dry yeast, and threw all the ingredients into my Kitchenaid bowl to knead for 5 minutes (proofing not necessary). Rather than adding garlic to the dough, I grated 2 cloves of garlic into 1/4 cup melted butter. I rolled out the dough and brushed each side with garlic butter before grilling (roll out, brush a side, grill that side and brush the raw side before flipping). Great flavor, perfect texture, little bubbles in each piece. If you're not getting bubbles, don't work your dough too hard - one good roll out from the center in either direction is enough, and the dough should still retain enough gas to create bubbles.

country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe when I first moved to TZ and didn't have an oven.  I was missing bread.  We then opened a restaurant here geared at expats and this naan was a cornerstone of the menu.  We served it with dips and with soups.  It is delicious and it's very difficult to mess up.  We let it rise for the recommended hour and then roll it into balls and place on a cookie sheet.  We  cover leftovers with plastic and keep in the refrigerator for 2-3 days.  A yummy variation is to add 1 tsp of cumin rather than the garlic.  A fun thing for young kids is to use cookie cutters and make naan bread in the shapes of animals and such!

city:

country:
None
text:
So I used all the same ingredients with a bread machine and came out good! After the bread machine dough cycle was done, I separated them into individual balls and left them to rise.  They rose a little bit, but not too much--but still ended up baking and tasting fine.  I made mine on a george foreman grill, worked better than on a pan on the stove.  I made some regular ones, and also cinnamon sugar ones.  I personally preferred the cinnamon sugar ones.  For those--I put the rolled dough on the grill, put melted butter, then a mixture of cinnamon sugar sprinkled on top and closed the GF grill.  After a couple mins I flipped it, and did the same by adding the butter and cinammon sugar; I closed the GF grill, waited a couple minutes, and done.  Tasted kinda like a cinammon sugar flat yummy pretzel.

country:
None
text:
SOOO SOOO GOOD! Not exactly like the restaurants, but soooo delicious everyone was eating it on its own! Used the bread machine on 'dough' setting which made it really easy. Found that rolling it out as thin as possible made it crispy and so we preferred it a little on the thicker side. Skillet works well, but the grill gave it an awesome smokey texture. With the 3.5 cups of flours suggested by others, the dough was too sticky to roll out. I will be going with 4-4.5 cups next time! Doubled the garlic and did not need to use any of the 'bubbling' tricks.

5

city:

country:
None
text:
OK, I really liked this.  First of all, it was just plain fun to throw dough on the grill.  As a freshly minted vegan guy who loves his outdoor cooking I was excited to find this naan recipe.  It never occured to me that I could make naan without the tandori oven.

IMPORTANT:  In step 1, the directions omit adding sugar to the water to proof the yeast. If you're not familiar with breadmaking, look up how to proof yeast before attempting this recipe.

I used freshly ground whole wheat with added gluten.  I also used corn starch + water in place of the egg and soy milk.  I know, it sounds like I made a different recipe.  The Naan was denser than it would have been otherwise, but still fairly fluffy (the added gluten helped, I think) and really tasty.

I served it topped with freshly made hummus, diced tomato, and grilled summer squash. It was a filliing and healthy meal.  I was quite pleased with myself. :-)  ...and I got to slap dough on the grill like I knew what I was doing.

text:
I cooked this on my baking stone in the oven so that it would be more similar to naan cooked on a tandoori.  It was great!  I recommend using a garlic press rather than mincing the garlic so that it is more evenly distributed and you won't get any small chunks of uncooked garlic in your bread.  I also let the dough rise in my oven on the lowest heat covered with a damp towel and the door open, and it only took about 30 minutes to rise.  It's a good option if you're short on time.

None
text:
This recipe gets 3 stars...for now. Most naan recipes I've looked at online call for baking soda. I made this one ONLY because I was clean out of baking soda. The bread tasted fairly good, but it did not bubble and rise like traditional naan, and instead cooked into something that resembled a very dense pancake. 

My husband has served in Afghanistan and ate a lot of traditional flat bread while there, and basically said that this recipe hardly even resembled naan. I'm going to experiment with it a bit and see if adding baking soda helps with the textural problems. As is, it's still a fairly good, edible flat bread and I can think of a million uses for it, but it's no Indian naan.

text:
Would've been five stars, but cooking on grill was a bit tricky to make the dough lie flat... quite a process actually. Delicious though, a big hit! Will make again but when I cook it on the grill will try doing it in bigger pieces instead of the small pancake size servings of naan. Seems it would be easier to make bigger and then tear as you eat it. Loved it though, especially with the garlic, but would recommend using more than suggested, or mixing garlic with the melted butter and then brushing that mixture on. So excited to find a recipe to make naan at home!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took a chance today on trying this to take to a picnic along with Hummus III from this site, and I'm so glad I did.  I was nervous it wouldn't work out and time was tight so it was something from the store if it didn't, but happily I didn't have to go to the store.  I will say the rising time is definitely longer than 1 hr initially (and yes I did proof the yeast) unless you help it along a little.  I turned my oven on for about 30 seconds and then off and put it in there helping it along somewhere warmer than room temp.  Rolling out the dough and grilling was surprisingly quick.  I opted to stir some garlic into my butter instead of putting in the dough, and cooked on low-med heat on the grill, about 2 minutes per side.  Loved the bread, just sweet enough and super yummy with the Hummus.

text:
SO Delicious!  I made this quickly last night on a whim to serve with a chickpea tikka masala. I usually buy naan at the grocery store, but didn't this time. Since it was just for the two of us, I halved the recipe.  I used fresh garlic from my own garden and it was fabulous.  I cooked the naan on a George Foreman style Swedish grill and it was perfect.  I didn't really "pull" the dough as much in the first couple of pieces, but by #3, it was chewy, crispy goodness. It was so much better than the store bought variety.  It tasted like and was the consistency of what is served in authentic Indian restaurants.  We had it for dinner and again with lunch today and can't wait to make it again!

text:
Quite honestly, I think this is a really good pizza dough. We did like this, but just not as good as we like-it was good just not a traditional tasting naan. I will make this again, since it is the best I've found. Plus, now I have a new pizza dough recipe. This is very versatile and can be seasoned according to one's preferences. I took the suggestion of one and added sugar to my yeast and warm water in order to proof. Let this rise in a slightly warmed oven. I grilled this on my George Foreman. Also, I used AP flour as I did not have bread flour. This is a good basic dough.

This is my first attempt at making flatbread and I just won't bother looking any further for a recipe.  This recipe turned out perfectly!  I used the suggestion of chopped garlic and it was wonderful - so buttery and garlicky!  I usually buy Naan bread to serve as the base for individual pizzas - but I'm not going to bother spending a dime at the grocery store for the packaged variety . Do yourselves a favour and give this a try!  I wish I could give it 10 stars!

text:
This was my first try at making naan and my husband says it was good.  We followed the recipe and used our grill.  We did put crushed garlic into the ghee when we brushed the naan.  It really makes a nice difference.  We both noticed it was a little sweet with 1/4 c. of sugar.  Next time I'll leave it at the 1 Tbsp. of sugar for proofing.  You don't need baking powder to achieve the little bubbles.  We used the grill on high and rolled the dough fairly thin.  If you have thick dough, the bubbles won't show as much.  We'll use this again.  Thanks, Mic.

text:
Wow just got done making this naan and it is really good. The changes from the instructions that I made were that I used just 1/4 cup of the water with the yeast and 1 tsp of sugar and proofed it and then followed the rest of the recipe adding the remaining water with the other ingredients. I will be using this as a flatbread for my taco dinner tonight. I will also use less sugar next time cause the naan tastes a little sweet. Overall this recipe is a keeper!

text:
I thought this naan was outstanding. I followed the recipe, and had to play around a bit with the grilling before it started turning out the way I expected. I learned I should roll the dough very, very thin. Medium-high heat was enough. I also stopped buttering anything until it was done. In the dry pan, it bubbled and puffed up beautifully. Adding the butter afterward helped the flavor of our dinner, but it seemed to hinder the bubbling if I added it during cooking. I will definitely be making this again!

I made a veganized version of this recipe.  I think this recipe is really good and hard to screw up, but I did modify it per other reviewers.  I used 2.5 c bread flour, 1 c whole wheat flour, and replaced the milk with soy milk and used EnerG egg replacer for the egg.  I also added 1/2 tsp of baking soda to make it bubble.  It was delicious.  Like an elephant ear (minus the sugar and cinammon).  My son kept wanting more.

text:
I made this a few nights ago for an impromptu Indian themed dinner. Let me tell you this recipe makes some great naan. I followed the proofing directions on the package of yeast that I used and had great success. I added about 1/2 teaspoons of baking soda(recommended by another reviewer) for extra bubbles, and I did not use all the butter that was called for in the recipe. I cooked my naan on my electric griddle(at 375)which I lightly greased and seasoned with fennel and cardamon seeds. Fantastic recipe over all, it allowed me to make tons of fluffy, yummy naan at a fraction of the cost compared to the local Indian eateries in the area.

text:
This recipe is really good. I was tired of picking through the limited selection of Naan bread at my local supermarket, set out to find a recipe to make on my own and this was perfect! I added goat cheese (couldn't find paneer in the market) by rolling out the balls, placing it in the center, then pressing the dough around the cheese before cooking it to mimic the cheesy naan bread we get at the restaurant, and it was perfect. My boyfriend is in love with naan and curry and you should have seen the look on his face after he tasted this bread with the chicken tikka masala that I made him! It was a look of pure ecstasy and satisfaction brought on by food!!

text:
I've never had naan before but I made it for a World Vision house party potluck that had the theme of food around the world to go with a Dominican stew that I made.  I used fast-acting/bread machine yeast so I wouldn't have to proof it (you just add it at the same time as the other ingredients at once) and made it on an electric griddle.  It was definitely easy to make and tasted good.  It was sweeter than I expected (though not sweet per se).  I think next time I'd make it with a little more salt and a little less sugar, but I guess it wouldn't be authenic. :)  Thanks for the recipe. :)

text:
I have a naan recipe that I have been using for years, and it is ok - but nothing close to the light fluffy bread you get at indian restaurants, so I decided to try this one.  I replaced the milk with kefir and used mostly fresh milled flour - so it was a whole wheat naan.  I LOVED these.  And I loved cooking them on the grill.  I have both cooked naan in the oven and pan fried it (West Indian version - roti) but this was by far the best way to cook it - and the easiest.  I froze some of the dough after the first rising and will use it later.

userID:
3553522
Display Name:
Bethundra
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/182022.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had my doubts as I was kneading this dough. Not wanting to purchase bread flour, I removed 4 tbsps of AP and added the same of Vital Wheat Gluten. The dough was incredibly tough to knead and it took three hours for it to rise even a little.   Before cooking, I heated a cast iron pan in the oven to get it nice and hot. I rolled out my balls of dough (they did soften a bit as they sat), which made close to 20 huge pieces. I carefully placed them in the dry pan for no more than 1 min. each side. They bubbled and darkened perfectly! As they were removed, I brushed them with a little butter and garlic.  The end result is great. They're the perfect combination of chewy and soft (the gluten really made these work). I wrapped up the leftovers in foil and brought them to work today. They're even better reheated in the microwave for 30 seconds.

userID:

Display Name:
motty

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/132452.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is fantastic. It turned out even better than at my favorite Indian restaurant. Just be certain to only add the flour a little at a time. I only needed about 3 1/2 cups. I also didn't knead the garlic into the dough. I just put it in the melted butter and let it sit for awhile, then brushed it on. And for desert, I just brushed plain butter onto the naan, then sprinkled it with cinnamon and sugar right after I pulled it out of the oven.  I don't have a grill, so I made it in the oven. I put a caste aluminum pan in the oven preheated it to 400 degrees, then followed all the cooking times according the recipe. I also didn't need to grease the pan at all. Enjoy!

Wonderful recipe ! To cut calories I do not brush with butter. They are still Awesome. I make a large batch hoping to have some for later and no matter how many I make they seem to disappear. I serve them with soup, hummus, steak dinner, you name it! I even get rave reviews from people who aren't inclined to eat Indian food. You can substitute these for any pita recipe too. For anyone on WW, if you do not use butter and other wise make as directed (14 servings) they are only 2 points each!!!

I wanted to make this for a party of 40 people this week, so I was determined to make it work. I had to make it EIGHT TIMES over the past couple weeks before I finally got the results everyone has been raving about. The trick for me was not to roll them too thin and *especially* to cook them in the oven at 400 degrees for no more than 2.5 minutes each side. I brushed one side with basil pesto and the other with olive oil and I couldn't be happier. OH SNAP.

text:
This turned out delicious. I don't think it's quite as puffy as traditional naan, but for my first time making it, it was great with tandoori chicken & basmati rice.     i think for me that the biggest issue was that the dough was very difficult to work with. i used at least 5c of flour (which was ap, not bread). it was very very sticky and it stuck to everything. kneading by hand was impossible. i used my stand mixer for about 8min and got a very nice dough, but again, it was so sticky that my hands were covered by the time I rolled it over to coat with oil.     otherwise, i would easily make this again. great taste and very fast to cook up.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe just as it states but had to throw out the 1st. batch of dough. The second try was much better, althougth I am not sure what the problem was in the first place.  I cut 1.5 cups of the flour out, added 1 more tbs. of milk and more salt.  I also included 1 tsp. of baking powder.  When mixing the yeast.  I added 1/4 of the sugar and the rest I added to the dry mix.  I did okay rolling out the dough but find it much easier to use a tortilla press.  I also allowed the dough to rise longer.  As for pans, I used a cast iron pan but didn't like to irony taste, my third batch tasted better to me using a coated cast iron pan.  These went very well with my lamb gyro sandwiches.

text:
This was awesome! Very time consuming, but totally worth it. I used this with Sean's Falafel recipe and it was fantastic. Since the falafel had a garlic sauce already I just left the garlic out of the bread. I thought the taste and texture of this was much closer to Greek pita bread than Indian Naan bread, but that is okay because it was excellent either way. TIP: If you want to use these as Pita or wraps, make sure you make the balls of dough bigger than a golf ball- other wise it comes out much too small to wrap anything up in. Thanks for the awesome recipe!

Tasted great but was more like pita bread than naan bread. text:
I've searched for a naan recipe for years, have literally tried over a dozen variations.  This is it!  Texture, appearance & taste rivaled the best Indian restaurant version.  Just me so I halved the recipe and went a little lighter on the flour.  Roll out time, I dusted the board/roller generously.  I think the lighter dough increased the rise.  I've made this 3 times in as many days with slight measurement variations because I'm sloppy with that and there was no problem.  I'm in a dry, high altitude area BTW.  I'm glad to quit the search for the perfect naan.

text:
Simple tasty recipe. Explore variations of seasoning if you like. I enjoy a splash of onion powder and a pinch of cayenne in the dough.  Chopped cilantro or parsley can be added too. I use yogurt instead of milk because I like that tang. Double up on the recipe and store extra dough in the fridge for the next day! Nothing else will do for the family once they have tasted this bread though. I use a tortilla press to flatten the dough before cooking, works well and goes much faster than rolling it out, also you don't dry it out with all the extra four needed for rolling.

Display Name:
Voox

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Soooo good! I really didn't make any changes except I added 1 TBS of sugar for the first rising period because other reviewers said to "proof" the yeast. I didn't kneed in garlic, but instead when I was grilling, I added garlic powder to the butter and just spread it on there. I'm not sure why there were so many reviews regarding the "secret" to making it bubble, because ours came out very bubbly. To get it flat, you sort of just "shake" it out to get it to stretch and then just pull out the areas that are still thick. Absolutely delicious and so easy to make! Also-- definitely do it on the grill and make sure to not over cook it on each side.

text:
Best homemade naan recipe I've tried yet (and I've tried a lot of them from online sources).  The only substitution I made was to use re-constituted powdered skim milk instead of regular milk - worked like a charm!  My dough didn't rise all that much during the first rising, so I was a bit nervous, but by the end of the second rising, I got a soft, smooth, beautifully pliable dough that stretched perfectly without making holes, and puffed up wonderfully in the pan!  Absolutely delicious!!! ^_^

text:
I read all of the reviews before making the naan and made it as follows... 1 Tbs yeast (I have a jar not a packet) and 1 Tbs sugar together in the water.  Put the minced garlic in directly with the other wet ingredients, taking out the work of kneading garlic into risen dough!!  I cooked the bread on a skillet at medium-high heat, buttering each side.  The resulting naan was delicious!

Excellent recipe.  I omitted the oil and made the dough and let it rise in a bread machine, I did need to add a small amount of additional water.  I've made this with and without garlic....definitely prefer it with garlic.  I've also tried using spray butter instead of real butter, just to make it a little easier/lighter.  There is a taste difference and I'll take the extra fat/calories and use real butter in the future.

country:
None
text:
My spouse thinks this is fantastic! I made it without the garlic because I wanted to taste what the basic recipe was like. I think I'll leave out the brushing with butter if I make them again, it seems to make them burn too fast and adds grease. I also found (like many of the other reviewers) that cooking them on the skillet worked best on a medium-low heat rather than high because they burn so very fast. I made this recipe because I was making curry, and it was the one that didn't call for yogurt (I don't have any). Maybe I'll try it with yogurt instead of milk next time and see if it tastes a bit more "authentic," as this seemed a little more like plain old flatbread to me that what I think of as naan. It was still tasty, though!

text:
This was great. I made a few changes: instead of adding chopped garlic I added a scant tablespoon (or less?) of garlic powder to the flour before mixing. I also used soy milk instead of milk. I made the dough in my bread machine, then made the balls and let them raise again. I pan fried them, since I don't have a grill. I had some dough that I didn't have time to cook, so I layerd it with parchment paper and froze it in a container. I made them last night and they were just as good as the first batch I made. Thanks for this recipe! (I served the Naan with chicken, peppers and onions sauteed with a little garlic and olive oil, it wasn't Indian, but it was good!)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been searching for a fantastic Naan recipe for years.  My search is over as this one meets theory and application.  I took the advice of other reviews i.e., added 1/2 t. of baking soda and grilled in a searing/grill pan on stovetop.  For "stretchiness" without being tough - I added 1 teaspoon of xanthum gum - big difference!  Bob's Red Mill offers a natural healthy xanthum gum.  If you really love Naan as our family and friends do - I guarantee, this recipe is sure to please.

text:
I am currently living in a dorm room in South Korea with two gas burners as my only means of cooking.  Since I cannot buy naan, I was looking for a way to make it and stumbled upon this recipe.  It's incredibly simple and I was successfully able to make it.  I used a frying pan at medium heat and a little oil in a non-stick pan.  Instead of rolling out dough I used my hands instead.  I did add the tablespoon sugar to the yeast mixture at the beginning and a teaspoon of baking soda so that my naan had bubbles when I cooked it.

PERFECT!!!

text:
This stuff is so good it's ridiculous.  I've made it at my co-op and at home several times and they all think I'm some kind of god when I make it.  It scales up very well.  I've had several people tell me it's better than what they get at Indian restaurants.  

I would advise people to not put in the garlic (and I'm a garlic nut)- it doesn't add much to the flavor and if you have extra in the morning, garlic-free naan tastes really wonderful with maple syrup.

text:
This produced wonderful naan, in spite of the fact that I had to make alterations to suit what I had on hand. I used four cups of all-purpose flour instead of bread flour, and used quick-rise yeast instead of the regular (this eliminated the second rise). The naan still puffed up beautifully in the oven. (I baked the naan at 450 degrees for about 4 minutes on each side, per directions.) I also added chopped Italian parsley in with the minced fresh garlic. Thanks for sharing--this is truly a treat my whole family enjoyed. We'll make this one again and again!

Just very dense as I mentioned. But these had a great flavor to them, and I actually knida liked how heavy they were. Great recipe in my opinion! Much better than the store-bought Naan I've tried.

text:
I have to echo the same opinions expressed by previous reviewers; these are delicious.  I halved the recipe using one small egg and it made fourteen pieces about 5 inches in diameter.  I made these in a grill pan on the stove over medium-high heat.  The only problem was that the butter created a good bit of smoke, so I’ll use ghee next time I cook it indoors as it has a much higher burning point than plain butter.  I can’t speak for authenticity since I haven’t had naan in several years, but this recipe was perfect with the curry I made.

My husband LOVED this bread. I halved the recipe so I could make it in my bread maker using the "dough" setting. We didn't include the garlic.  My husband cooked it on the BBQ grill and it puffed up nicely (we tried it with whole wheat bread flour the first time and it didn't puff up so nicely).  My husband LOVED the combination of this bread served with "Sharon's Scrumptious Souvlaki" (with a few variations to the recipe) from this site.

Fabulous!  This was easy to make and got rave reviews from both my husband and my 2-year-old.  I made these in our grill pan, as we don't have a bbq grill, and they came out just fine in the grill pan.  I did brush them with the melted butter, but found that they cooked without sticking to my grill pan, so I'll be able to omit the butter and make this recipe  for my in-laws, who are on a low-fat diet.

text:
I was able to try a number of suggestions here just from the volume of dough this recipe makes.  Someone had suggested putting a little baking soda on the pan and covering it to make the bread bubble.  While it did bubble, it had a bitter aftertaste, even with just a little baking soda.  I also tried it on the grill and in the frying pan.  On the grill it worked okay, but in the frying pan it worked out the best on medium heat, it even bubbled some and came out very chewy and nice.  I think adding the garlic is a must.  Very nice recipe...my favorite part of Indian cuisine.

text:
I have made this 2X's.  The first time, it was tasty, but not quite right.  Second time, my dough didn't rise and I couldn't grill them so I had to use my cast iron griddle and they came out PERFECT, go figure.  I think the secret is buttering a griddle and not grilling them.  The second time, I also split the dough in half.  Added the garlic to one half and a ground almond/raisin paste that I made to the other.  The almond raisin Naan dissapeared first.  Will be making this often.

text:
Little bit too sweet as written.  Also, NOTE:  If you wish to cook stovetop (as I did), griddle / fry pan should be warmed as for pancakes (about midway on my gas stovetop control knob).  Only takes about 45-50 seconds per side to cook if thin enough (press bubbles down).  Sadly enough, they do not reheat well, so perhaps this would be good for a party or large dinner gathering.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
Excellent recipe!!! Soft and slightly sweet bread that was great as a side dish to chicken curry. Like others commented, it stole the show over the main dish! I did not try adding the garlic, preferred the simple taste to contrast with the spicy curry. Also did not add butter when grilling...no need for it in my opinion. I used a frying pan with Pam to grill them for about 2 minutes per side on medium/low head. This worked great. Will make this again! Maybe I'll try the grill when it's not 5 below zero!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have a yeast packet, so I used 2 1/4 tsp of active dry jarred yeast. And I've learned from other recipes to have warm water around 105-110° to not kill the yeast. I added a dash of the sugar to just the yeast and water, and let it foam for 5-10 minutes. Then I mixed in the ingredients in a stand mixer with the dough hook attachment.  Be careful not to let the salt and yeast come in direct contact. Put it in after some flour.

Display Name:
Katie Meier

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I’ve made it multiple times and every one who tries it immediately loves it. However, I did make a few alterations. For example, the recipe calls for 4 and 1/2 cups of flour, and it tells you to use enough to make a soft dough. For me, this has been about 3 and 1/2 cups every time. I also increased the rising time for the second rise, going from 30 to 45 minutes. Next, the recipe has you use melted butter and a grill to cook the bread. As I have been making this in winter, I don’t have access to a grill so I have been using a cast iron skillet, and it works great. But, if I use butter I think it will burn, so I have been using olive instead and it works just as well. Once again, great recipe.

userID:
26320067
Display Name:
Jenny Spence
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7179925.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe worked quite well for me, but was a little sweeter than I like. I will make it again, but reduce the sugar by a third to start, and go from there. I measured the flour and sugar out, and then took a tablespoon of each to prove my yeast so as not to add any additional sugar or flour beyond the recipe. I also found 3 1/2 cups flour (plus flour to kneed) to be sufficient (thanks to other reviewers for this tip!), and rather than kneeding garlic into the dough, I added it to the melted butter that I brushed the grilling naan with, making sure some of the actual garlic ended up on the bread, not just the flavored butter. 

The other thing I did a little differently was I used my instant pot (on the low yogurt setting) as a proving drawer to speed up my first rise, as our house tends to be too cold for a countertop rise. It only needed about 35 minutes to double in size rather than the hour stated in the recipe. Over all, the naan was a big hit, and I will make it again with the only modification being to reduce the sugar a bit.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-09-16T06:54:46.697

text:
I added bit of Baking Soda like another reviewer said.  Make sure to leave enough time to rise. Also mix in at least a tablespoon of sugar with the initial yeast and water to foam.  If it doesnt foam stop there and likely you should get new yeast.  I would put the garlic into the butter while rising to flavor it and use to brush them at the end.  Much better than mixing butter into the dough.  These were very goodl Made me 20 small naan.  2 - 3 would fit in my cast iron grill.

I made this twice. The first time I used 4 1/2 cups of flour but it was too much. The second time I used 3 1/2 cups, as other reviewers indicated, and it worked great. We have a gas stove so I cooked more naan over the open flame and it bubbled just like what you see in the restaurant. I used our pizza screen to hold the naan while it cooked over the open flame.

text:
This is very good Naan. I followed the recipe using Bread Flour. Made it in my bread maker so the first rise was completed there. The dough looked kind of dry to start but came together in the end. It is a dense dough. After making the small balls and the second rise I rolled the dough out quite thin and then cooked on the BBQ which allowed me to do 5-6 at a time. They bubbled up perfectly and everyone loved them. This is a keeper.

189
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4594525.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used black pepper and onion powder in place of the garlic (forget to pick some up so improvised). It worked really well but used  a bit too much onion powder...

With that said, if anyone else is interested in using onion powder, try 1/2 tsp onion powder and about 1 tsp pepper. 1:1 is a bit too much... Live and learn.

Also, for anyone using a gas stove, medium-low heat for about 30 seconds was perfect for me. Any higher/longer would have burned.

Almond/cashew milk can be substituted no problem for dairy milk and the sugar can be reduced or omitted completely depending on your tastes. I used 1/8 cup of Stevia and it turned out fine.

Overall, fantastic recipe that allows for plenty of customization for different tastes and dietary requirements. Thanks so much for sharing it, Mic!

Rating:
5

text:
This recipe was great. My husband as actually very pleased and we both know I'm not a very good cook/baker. It took a little while longer than anticipated even having read the reviews to make sure to allot time for rising. I followed the receipt but used 3 1/2 cups all purpose flour and let it knead in my Kitchen Aid for 6 minutes however I think I probably should have cut that down to 3-4. The naan ended up being a little tough. I melted the butter and let the garlic sit in the butter as someone else had recommended however it lost some of the potency that way so I think next time I would knead it in. Cook on medium on my gas burning stove with a cast iron skillet. Over all turned out pretty good. I think I would try ghee next time instead of real butter. I had some extra balls so I put them in the freezer. We'll see how those turn out! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I will definitely make this again! It was very delicious! I only made minor adjustments which I normally do not do when I review a recipe. One was to add sugar to the yeast. When I mixed the water with just the yeast, it didn't froth or bubble, so I threw it out and started over. The second time I added a pinch of sugar and it worked perfectly so I began the rest of the process. I only added 1/8th of a cup if sugar because I am super sensitive to sweets, and cooked it in a pan on the stove because I do not currently own a grill. Overall, the recipe is great! My family loved it, and I will definitely be making it again!

text:
I made this last night and took suggestion from a reviewer about adding a 1/2 tsp of baking soda to get more bubbles. This worked out and I recommend this. However a note about flour for the Canadian bakers. Canadian flour is heavier so when making this the ratios seemed weird to me, 1 cup plus 3 T of milk did not seem like it would hydrate 4.5 cups of flour. I added in 1/2 cup portions and only ended up needing 3.5 cups.

text:
FINALLY got this right! I only used 2 Tbl sugar during the proofing stage. no more than that. Also, high heat is ridiculous, has to be like cooking anything else on a griddle, a little higher than medium. Frying with butter is problematic, it spits a lot. I used oil, but that makes the naan brittle. Next time I'll try butter on a lower heat. But this batch with lower amounts of sugar was for sure the best.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is AMAZING. I have little experience cooking bread or Indian cuisine of any kind, and this turned out perfectly. The hot bread melts right in your mouth. A few tips from my experience: 
Add a little sugar to your yeast and warm water right away, this will give you the "frothiness" the instructions talk about and will help the dough rise more during the first proofing......
Mix minced garlic in with your melted butter and let it sit for a minute before you start grilling, this gives great flavor without having big pieces of garlic in the dough.....
A George Foreman grill works just fine if you don't have a grillpan, brush it with olive oil first.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've been making this regularly  since I first printed it out in 2001. It's probably the best thing I make.
Some advice: "bread' flour is not necessary--regular unbleached white does fine. And yes as one reader points out--do be sure to put a little of the sugar in the warm water when proofing. Don't bother with the garlic. Serve with a little kosher salt.
You can minimize the kneading by adding flour a cup at a time, stirring until each cup is incorporated.
I find it takes about three hours from the minute I start assembling ingredients to when the last naan comes off the grill.

text:
Absolutely incredible!!! My husband couldn't stop eating it. As with any bread recipe, add flour little by little so as not to make the dough too stiff. I also included a 1/2 tsp of baking soda, thanks to another reviewer's tip, and had no problems getting bubbles to pop up while cooking the Naan. I didn't have a grill so I used a frying pan instead which worked great! And instead of incorporating garlic into the dough, I followed another's recommendation to mix it in with the butter brushed on top while cooking. Mmm.

I paired this Naan with a tasty Indian Chicken Curry. The Naan definitely helped to balance out and tone down the hotness of the curry.  Would definitely recommend!

text:
I made this recipe today, it was the first time I ever made naan, and it was amazing. I cooked it in a very hot oven on a baking stone and then transferred to the oven rack to brown. It had many big bubbles, was crisp on the outside and tender & elastic on the inside.  It is very important to allow the yeast to bloom with  water and sugar first and to use high gluten content flour for best results. I used King Arthur's bread flour.  This was better than restaurant naan bread. Thanks for posting this recipe. We love it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is so easy and yummy as written.  I grill it on my electric crepe pan slightly less than full out (7 out of 8).  They cook quickly and get the char you see at the restaurant.  The only other thing I do slightly differently is to par cook the garlic when I melt the butter.  Putting both in a glass measuring cup and cooking 1 1/2 minutes on high in the microwave takes out the raw garlic taste and flavors the butter too.  Then I remove the garlic - most of it floats - with a  spoon and add it to the dough and knead it in.

text:
Tried this for the first time, and did some experimenting with my Weber gas grill.  All turned out great!  First cooked some on the grates. They had nice grill marks and texture.  Then I removed a grate, put a naan pan on the heat distribution panels, much closer to the heat source.  These turned out even better.  Then tried to roll them out thinner, using the grate and the pan.  They were good, but lost the texture of a true naan, so don't roll them too big.

userID:
13549066
Display Name:
Kristi Howell
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
34
favoritesCount:
398
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1539840.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe (halve the amount of sugar and use it while proofing) but different cooking method.  Divide dough into 2 oz pieces.  During second rise, preheat well-seasoned cast iron skillet in hot oven -- just so it's evenly heated when you move it to the stove top.   Roll out each portion of dough into a disc, place on sheet pan and keep covered with a towel.  They'll continue to rise a bit, which makes a much lighter naan.  Place a dough disc on hot DRY skillet over med-low heat until it puffs up nicely all over.  (It happens pretty quickly!)  Flip and cook until the bubbles just start to char.   If desired, brush cooked naan with garlic butter.  Freezes well.  Makes 16.  Don't skimp on the salt.
Review:
Rating:
5

I love this recipe. I modified this a bit to my liking, but you can try too:

Cut down sugar by half.
Added 6 table spoons of extra virgin olive oil.
Replace milk with greek yogurt. (less important than the others above)
Grill it on the gas stove. It turned out like a hollow bread when I put in an oven.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2727709.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like other reviewers, I made the mix in the bread machine and cut the flour down to 3.5 cups. When I pulled it out, I punched it down and then let it rest for five minutes. Then, I made little balls, wrapped them in plastic, and refrigerated them overnight for a party the next day. Wow! They grew like gremlins in the refrigerator overnight, and when I opened the door they had populated the space. Hilarious side effect! Anyway, the next day, I rolled them out, dredged them in butter infused with fresh chopped garlic, and fried them on high heat until brown on each side. I served them with a vegetarian curry at a party, and they were a hit! I will definitely make this recipe again. (BTW - I also took the advice to make two small balls and mush them into one to create space between layers in the final product, and it worked well.)

None
text:
Great recipe! I did cook it a little differently to make it bubble up..
Let it rise twice, rolled it out and stacked them on top of each other while cooking. I put a piece in a dry, non-stick pain with a lid, cooked it on medium-high heat until the bottom was brown and bubbles were forming on the top. Flipped, covered and cooked for another minute. Brushed with ghee and sprinkled with garlic salt. Serve. 
Deeeelish!

text:
I just made this today and it turned out wonderful!! Now i have never baked anything that requires yeast before so i had a lot of trouble at first proofing the yeast until i read the package which said to add sugar, i did use a bit less water and less flour which made the dough somewhat thicker but it still feels light and fluffy. I added some garlic paste to the butter instead of needing it into the dough, i honestly like my naan plain but this way jt was not an overwhelming garlic taste. I don't have a pin so i was spreading out the dough outwards with my hands, the first piece came out really thick though, i hadn't anticipated the dough rising so much while cooking. I started spreading them really think and they came out perfect afterwards.

country:

text:
Excellent recipe!  This dough is very, very easy to work with and came out perfectly.  We added a whole bunch of fresh cilantro and FRESH garlic.  If you don't have a grill or grill pan, you can also do this in a hot cast iron (or other pan).  It cooks quickly, so do it on high, about 90 seconds on the first side and 60 seconds on the second.

This also freezes beautifully, so after it was completely cooled, we froze in zip locks in packs of two.  But it was so good that the stash didn't last a week!

We are now going to make a double recipe at least monthly and keep a supply in the freezer for wraps and hummus.

Display Name:
Glosgirl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2565578.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Brilliant recipe. Have been looking for a great recipe for naan for a very long time. 

As one of the previous reviewers said, the secret really is in getting it as thin as you can - I found that a combination of rolling out and stretching with my hands until parts of it were papery thin was the best way to get the results I wanted. 

As for the cooking, I preheated my oven to 450F with a pizza stone on the top shelf, and then switched to hi-broil. I was trying to simulate a tandoor oven! It seemed to work pretty well, and I think I've finally found a recipe I can work with! 

I always add onion seeds to my naan; I'm originally from the UK, and this is pretty much the standard - gives a nice savoury flavour - (those are the black specks in the photo I submitted). 

I did find the flavour was slightly lacking - possibly a lack of salt, or maybe that I just wasn't eating it with melted butter infused with garlic, that made it feel like something was missing - probably the latter, hence the 5 stars for amazing texture and results! :)

text:
I made these and even though they yeast didn't froth up (which seems to be a common problem for a lot of people after asking google the question!) the dough did rise, not double in size but they rose more once into individual balls. 
They were easy to flatten out and again although they didn't puff out while cooking they still tasted great. 
I didn't add the garlic to  the dough, I just spread with garlic butter during the cooking on both sides. They were a hit on the night and I will definitely make these again and learn before then how to get the yeast frothing properly!! 
So hopefully they can be even better.

Made a half recipe of this and it turned out well! I made some modifications - followed the yeast proofing instructions on the packet, used water in place of milk, omitted the garlic, set riding dough in front of heater, cooked in a sautée pan - and the final product still turned out great. I also decided to use the remaining half of egg to brush the naan before putting it on the stove; gave it a nice brown and shine. The only things I'd do differently: I'd try brushing with garlic and butter, and keep more flour handy (as the dough was a little stickier than expected). Yum!

This recipe is amazing! I added 2 Tsp. Baking soda to the mixture, as another person suggested, and 4 cups of flour is plenty, so I wouldn't suggest more than that. Also, I put minced garlic in with the butter, instead of kneading it in. It's much easier. Everyone LOVED them. They are so good even by themselves. I even left the dough to rise 6 hours so I could get some sleep, then split them into balls in the morning and cooked them. It worked just the same!

text:
So...mixed bag here. To me, this recipe isn't your traditional naan. It tasted more like Italian bread sticks. So if that's what you're wanting, by all means, cook away! They're great for that. 

But for naan, they tasted too yeast-y. Also, if you're going to make these as naan, make sure you get them REALLY thin before you put them on the grill. Probably wouldn't make again as naan...but not bad if you're looking for a pizza crust or bread sticks.

userID:
8715801
Display Name:
Bailstorm
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
88
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe, the best flavour of any Naan breads. The salt is necessary for the correct flavour but I only add half the sugar, which I add to the yeast as well. I allow my dough to rise in the oven which had been on low for a few minutes then turned off prior to popping the dough in. I find this speeds up the rising time.I make sure my cast iron grill is brushed with butter prior to each one being made If you are as big a Naan bread fan as my family is, the best TIP of all to get those fabulous bubbles is to roll the dough out very thin, very thin about 1/16" thin. It will puff up when cooked to the perfect thickness. Try it you will be surprised!! Any thicker and you won't get the bubbles. It will cook quickly this thin so watch carefully.
Review:

text:
I usually make bread to please my husband's tastes, which is a couple of times a week. This time I chose something I wanted and now he asks for it. This bread is easy, and delicious. It goes with all types of foods and main dishes. It stores nicely in a zip lock bag, and reheats well too. It can be seasoned not only with the cilantro leaves but sprinkled with just about any desires spice blend you love. This is my new substitute for the standard homemade tortillas I've made for years. The extra time for a yeast based dough is worth it.

I can't say I'm a naan expert, but this recipe was very close to what my favorite restaurant does with theirs, I will absolutely be making this one again.

This was so easy to make & my family went CRAZY for it! I did make a few changes to the directions. I let my Kitchen Aid mixed knead it for me, I kneaded for about 6 minutes on low. I then followed all the directions as stated. I made a pizza from the uncooked dough & it was incredible!! This is my new go to flatbread from now on. I am thinking of all the things I can make with it. I do know it freezes good, because when I have bought it in the store sometimes its still slightly frozen. I made 2 batches of dough so, I'm going to do layers of parchment between the layers and freeze some of them.

Siri Brown

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2751756.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I didn't bother letting the dough rise much, being short on time. My bread still bubbled up nicely. To keep the air in, I did not roll them... I tossed them like pizza dough.  I undercooked them slightly to ensure that they were moist, and I did add the extra 1/2 tsp. baking soda that another reviewer suggested, just in case. I went a little light on the flour to keep them tender. I also raised them in a 100 degree oven. I added the garlic, but its taste was extremely subtle. I wouldn't have guessed it was there, but it added that little bite that it needed. I don't have a grill.. made them in the frying pan with a tiny bit of canola oil. I think the grill would have dried them. After cooking wrapped them together for warmth and moisture. The result was light, tender, moist, full of flavor, melted in our mouths.. Family argued over the last piece!!

text:
Fantastic, fantastic, fantastic! I've made it repeatedly since finding the recipe years ago. My only tip is don't do the flour by exact measure do it by dough consistency. I add the final cup of flour a bit at a time and stop once the dough pulls clean away from the sides ( I use a kitchenaide stand mixer with dough hook). I freeze the dough and use I for all types of recipes, pizza, pigs in a blanket, even pretzels. Awesome stuff. My family begs for flat bread or pigs in a blanket for every holiday! Make it, you'll love it!

text:
I followed some previous advice and used 3 cups of flour and then 1/2 a cup to knead it. I added a dash of baking soda. I got good results although I cooked it in an iron skillet rather than over an open fire. The hardest part was getting the thickness correct. I learned that I really had to roll it pretty thin to get the thickness I desired. The addition of the baking soda made it nice and bubbly.  Next time I'll go to the trouble of lighting the grill. It will be worth it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Naan is one of our favorite things, and I'm always on the lookout for easy ways to make it. This is NOT the easiest way, but so far, it's the best. I followed the advice of several other reviewers and used about a cup less flour, and 6 T plain Greek yogurt in place of the milk. I skipped the garlic entirely, and used butter in the grilling pan-a cast iron skillet-instead of brushing it on. This version didn't "poof" as much as as some others I've tried, but it had a lovely, soft texture and a really good flavor; some have said that it's too sweet, but mine wasn't sweet at all, maybe because I didn't use any extra sugar to proof the yeast.

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great authentic taste! I didn't see the notes about using less flour until I started and noticed the dough was really dry. I added more water (about 1/3 c), and it was fine. This was my first time making naan, and although I made the dough by hand, I WILL USE MY MIXER next time to make the dough. Using a mixer to make the dough will take a lot of the work out of it. Other than that, it was pretty simple. I don't have a grill, so I did mine on the stove top in a non-stick skillet on medium-high heat. I didn't use any kind of cooking spray. I just plopped the rolled out dough into the hot pan. I noticed the thinner I rolled it, the more it puffed up. If you like your naan to "pocket", make it thinner. If you like it more "flatbread like", roll it thicker. I didn't have any ghee, so I used melted butter. It worked well, but the ghee will work better for next time. It was a fun, tasty project, and I will make it again!

Display Name:
JustSomeGuy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. Here is how I cooked it:
1. Heat iron skillet to max. Make sure you have a lid ready.
2. Lightly oil the pan.
3. Roll out your dough
4. Dip your hands in a container of water
5. Flip the rolled out dough from hand to had to wet it
6. Place the wetted dough in pan, cover with lid, and cook for about 60 seconds - no butter.
7. Flip the bread when you see it getting puffy. 
8. Cook for about 30 to 60 seconds more.
9. Remove from pan and apply butter as needed (optional).
If the bread burns before 60 seconds reduce heat. If it doesn't brown within 60 seconds increase heat. Using this method will produce COMPLETELY different results.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This was really good. I did the dough in the bread machine. I proofed the yeast first and mixed everything together except the flour, put it in the machine, and then put the flour in the machine. The dough dries out quickly though so take it out of the machine promptly. Roll out the pieces super, super thin. Then I cooked them on the george forman brushing them with garlic butter. Don't cook them too long because you want the bread soft not crunchy.

recipe is great as it stands....to get the bubbles, dont use a grill instead use a large cast iron skillet. oil generously with olive oil or grape seed oil. once you have rolled out a few, let them reast for 3-5mins then place them on the hot skillet, use tongs to flip. bubbles should appear quickly.

text:
Roast your Garlic!!!

Great recipe. I like it and made a couple of tweaks to it.

I used 3 tablespoons of sour cream instead of the milk, which gave it a slightly tart note. 

And roasted a head of garlic as I was making the dough. The roasted garlic is really nice and simply takes away the sharpness of the garlic. Chopped it up and kneaded it in easily because of its soft texture.

This will be great for dinner tonight!

text:
I made this and while time consuming, it tastes delicious!  I followed the recipe pretty closely, however I only had 2 cups of bread flour, so I substituted all purpose for the other 2.5 cups.  I also took other's advice and added a tsp of baking soda to see if it would help with the bubbles.  It may have, but it didn't bubble much at all.  I did cook this in a non-stick skillet on my stove...perhaps next time I'll try the George Foreman grill.  Definitely tasty with raita or tzatziki!  (Oh and I used my bread machine to make the dough and let it rise the second time by the fireplace.

text:
This made great naan!  I used my breadmaker for the dough...putting warm water & yeast in the bottom, then the sugar, milk, egg, flour & salt on top.  I had no trouble getting the nice little bubbles..but found I got more when I pressed them by hand rather than using a rolling pin...you do have to make sure to press them pretty thin.  I fried in coconut oil instead of butter...mmmmm.... My family loves it with the butter chicken recipe on here, too!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Good recipe, but with a few adjustments it could be even better. First, when you dissolve the yeast, add the sugar in at the same time. It gives the yeast something to "eat", and tends to give it a bit of a boost.Also, if you want to go a little more classic Indian, use ghee(clarified butter)in place of regular butter. Ghee is simply butter without the milk solids. To make it, melt the butter down on low heat(without stirring), and then scrape the white milk solids off the top.

text:
Made this last night, best Naan recipe I've come across yet! It was soft and not dry and chewy like a lot of recipes come out. I dissolved the yeast in the warm water and a tablespoon of sugar, then chucked it all in the breadmaker on dough cycle for 1.5 hours. Worked great! I kneaded in some garlic, and the brushed BOTH sides with butter and heaps more garlic (we looove garlic). Also, roll out the balls of dough as THIN as you can. Great recipe, thanks for sharing it!

Great recipe. It didn't quite taste authentic, to remedy this I substituted plain yogurt in place of the milk, and added 1 tbsp. Also you have to roll this out super super thin and you'll get those nice bubbly spots, and I have used a preheated cookie sheet that I heated to 450, and I've also cooked them in an iron skillet on the stovetop (not fried).

text:
This recipe, instead of making a soft dough, makes an incredibly firm dough. For a soft dough with an enriched dough recipe like this one, start with about a cup and a half of water.

my first attempt because the dough was so firm, I couldn't even knead in enough water to soften it up. Even assuming that my flour was dry, this recipe still seems way out of whack.

userID:
5621339
Display Name:
mblue
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Soooo good!  This turned out almost exactly like the Naan you get in Indian restaurants.  It was awesome, soft, and heavenly.  My 2 & 3 year old children loved it as well.  I didn't feel like heating up the grill & I don't have a gas stove like many make Naan on.  So, I heated up a non-stick skillet to medium heat & sprayed it with Pam & cooked my Naan on it till it got puffy & was lightly browned on the bottom.  Then, I flipped it & did the other side.  I brushed melted butter on both sides during cooking.  I was hesitant to try it this way because who has heard of Naan cooked on a non-stick skillet?  However, it turned out quite lovely.  It was soft, buttery, & just lovely.  Oh, & I did add about a tablespoon of vegtable oil to the dough when kneading it because it was really dense before hand.  The oil loosended it up a little- perfect!

madeRecipesCount:
60
favoritesCount:
106
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a huge win--and it came out great using my bread maker to make the dough.  There were two things missing from the recipe as it is:
1.  This does not serve 14.  This makes 25 pieces of naan, some of them oversized.  If you're serving for three or two, I suggest cutting the recipe down.  
2.  How flat should they be rolled?  We tried a few different ways and came to the conclusion that over-flattening them causes them to come out too crispy.  Still tasty, just more of a cracker texture.
I served this with Aloo Phujia over rice and had a great Indian dinner night.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great!
I used almond milk, and about a teaspoon of granulated garlic since I didn't have any fresh garlic to mince. 
My only problem was the dough ended up pretty sticky - I was able to work in about 3 1/4 cups of flour before I couldn't work anymore flour into it. 

When I was rolling out the dough balls I needed to add more flour to prevent the dough from sticking to me/the rolling pin/the waxed paper I was using.

Using a charcoal grill for this was a little hard, at first the dough was bubbling up great but the later pieces we threw on didn't bubble up as much which I think was because the charcoal wasn't as hot anymore. But it tasted great, we had it with fresh homemade tzatziki dip.

text:
This recipe didn't taste the way I had hoped. I was hoping for a Naan like the one I buy regularly. Despite not being quite what I wanted, it is a really great recipe. I've made it several times now, and my boyfriend is hooked on this. Like other reviewers, I didn't need as much flour as it calls for. This bread, more than some others I've made, seems sensitive to cold. Once I kicked the heat up 10 degrees in the house (to 75 degrees), it came out great! It turned out even better when I used a warm tray for the second rising. I will continue to make this. Thanks for sharing it!

text:
Excellent recipe.  I have made this several times, once on the grill, once in the oven, and my favorite- in a buttered skillet.  To get the dough really flat, press it down with the bottom of a cup, wait a few minutes, then repeat again and again until it is flat enough for you.  I used this as a crust for BBQ chicken pizza and it is wonderful!  I always proof the yeast first by adding the warm water and sugar to the yeast at once, I am not sure why the steps don't add the sugar in the first step.  GREAT RECIPE!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has potential, but it hasn't quite hit the mark for me as yet.  I used the bread maker (highly recommend) but added 4 c flour - 3.5 c would have been better to achieve soft dough.  Also, I found the dough too sweet for my liking (next time will reduce sugar by 50%).  Rising stages worked fine.  Used my wooden tortilla press to shape the individual naan, starting with an oval of dough.  Worked great - pressed between pieces of parchment.  As others have suggested, need to watch heat on BBQ - I have 3 elements so kept one high, one medium and one off, jugging the naan as needed.  This was an easy recipe and I will try again with a few modifications.

Easy to make. Family loved 'em. Roll them very thin (2-3mm) or leave them fat (5-10mm), either way they are soft and tasty. This is what our home-cooked Indian meals were missing.

text:
Superb nann!  I'll admit I was skeptical that this recipe would approximate the naan at our favorite gourmet Indian restaurant, despite the glowing reviews.  I did not use the optional garlic, and I would say this recipe is indistinguishable from the naan at The Gopuram. I cut back on the salt, but I believe it needs the full amount called for.  I will not be looking for another naan recipe.  This is exactly what I was hoping for.

text:
reallyy really good - we had it with an Indian chicken soup and even my boyfriend loved it and he usually does not like bread as a side :) I use one cup whole wheat flour (just to try and make it a little more healthy) - but i didn´t use the whole 4 1/2 cups of flour. I did add a little carbin.soda like someone suggested - and I made the ball from two pinches as well and rolled them into one ball like someone else suggested as well. I agree that the pan only needs to be med low - no way does it need to be very hot !! I put some garlic and koriander into the butter to brush the sides and it came out perfect - THANK YOU MIC :D

text:
Great Recipe. I also used this recipe with whole wheat flour and the outcome was great! The dough can be made in advance- and then frozen. I take it out 3 hrs before I start making the naans and it rises again and the naans come out just as well. Have also used the whole wheat dough as a pizza base to make thin crust pizzas. This recipe is so good, I will never eat store bought naans again!

text:
This recipe is excellent, I've halved the recipe several times an I have even used egg replacer and it comes out perfect every time.  I do think that making the entire recipe takes a good amount of time to cook in one fry pan, but it is definitely worth it. I rinsed out the fry pan several times in between frying a couple of breads to keep the pan from skoking.  I also didn't use butter to brush the tops of the bread afterwards because I thought it didn't need it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fairly easy and had a great flavor.  I recommend adding a bit of sugar to the warm water when you are dissolving the yeast as it helps with rising the dough a bit quicker. I also added some baking soda to help make it a little more bubbly but not really sure if it helps too much as I didn't see a huge change as I normally do when adding baking soda to recipes.  I baked half the recipe in a cast iron skillet and it turned out phenomenal: had that grill, charred flavor that is typical of naan. The other half I baked in the oven for 10 minutes at 375 and it resulted in a product EXACTLY like pita: pocket and all!  The only thing I noticed is that it didn't have a big garlic flavor so I will definitely be making garlic butter to spread over during the cooking process.  All in all, a keeper recipe!
Review:

I used one cup whole wheat flour and the rest white flour.  All the hard work was done by the dough cycle on my bread machine.  Then, I just broke off balls, rolled it out with my rolling pin, and cooked it in my big frying pan over the stove.  Incredible! I dipped the first cooked one in olive oil while I was standing at the stove cooking the rest....I didn't think I'd be able to stop eating it!

Display Name:
brooklyncooker

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this for the first time today and was halfway pleased with the way it came out.  Followed some of the reviewer's suggestions - some worked others didn't.  I forgot to add the baking powder as one suggested, but found I didn't need if for bubbles - the trick of pinching off a few separate balls and then rolling them together produced plenty of bubbles.  The adding garlic butter after did not work well for me.  I also used the stone baking method and the garlic and butter burned this way.  By the way, needed much more butter for these, next time I'll at least double the recipe recommendation.  Also, didn't like them so thin - the Naan breads I've had have always been thicker and more bread like - these had a sort of motzah feel to them, so next time I'll make them thicker.  I did like the flavor however, so I gave them 3 stars for now.  I think this is one of those recipes with a learning curve, so I'll probably re-rate them after attempting again - surely they were good enough for another shot at it. Thanks for posting.

Rating:
5

text:
This was fantastic!  Served with Chicken Tikka Masala and basmati rice.  My yeast didn't seem to activate very well (no frothing) and the ball didn't really double in an hour, but the bread was fantastic.  We  brush one side with butter and put that side down on the grill first, then butter the other side so the butter sides both got "cooked."  As directed in the recipe, we found it a little greasy.  I did NOT knead any garlic in and thought it was more flavorful than at our local Indian restaurant.

city:

country:
None
text:
Unfortunately, I don't own a pizza stone so I used a griddle (350 degrees).  So long as you roll them out very thin (VERY THIN), you can get the naan to appear naan-ish.  My first attempt gave us thick, kind of chewy in the center flat bread that wasn't horrible, but not completely appealing.  We made the entire batch of dough but only used a third of it.  I wrapped the remainder in wax paper and then stored it a plastic ziplock bag in the fridge.  Then, I completely forgot about it for over a week!  My man/kitchen-wizard discovered it and tried one suggestion to use the dough for pizza and it worked!  Then, a few nights later, we made more naan (this time he rolled it out very thin).  We found that the bread tastes better when you coat the griddle in butter first, cook on one side for about a minute, then flip.  So yummy!

This bread tastes delicious! The only thing I changed was omitting half of the salt. And I'm glad I did. The one thing that will keep me from making this frequently is the time it took to cook it. We don't have a grill so I just used a pan to cook them. Each one took 3 minutes or so, but I had to stand there the whole time and then put the next one in. Too time consuming, but very delicious! Thankful it makes a fair amount, I just threw the left overs in the fridge and put it in the toaster oven when I wanted to eat some more. I will cook this when I make butter chicken. Thank you for a DELICIOUS recipe though!

text:
Great recipe! Totally a keeper! I read a bunch of reviews and based on them I proofed the yeast first (added a tbl of sugar to the yeast and water), I didn't add the garlic to the dough but to the butter (I liked this suggestion a lot), I rolled the dough very thinly, and since I didn't have a grill I used an open George Foreman. It turned out great! The George Foreman was a pretty good substitute for a grill, even giving the bread the grill marks. I didn't have any problem with the dough, and I even put in half whole wheat flour to make it a little healthier. I paired this with Wendy's Indian Butter Chicken from this site and what a meal! I would recommend both recipes and they go great together :)
