I really liked this nana recipe I`ve never made nana before so I wanted it to turn out really great! and It did this dough CAN be frozen t after you make the dough and when your not ready to use it. when you are just unthaw.   I added the garlic and it was tasty.  I also used olive oil because that`s the only oil I use to cook with. But I have one critique:  Roll the dough  out thinly BEFORE you cook it if you don`t it will not rise and it WILL BE RAW ON THE INSIDE NO MATTER HOW BROWN IT LOOKS OUTSIDE!!!!   AND COOKING IT IN A SKILLET MAKES FOR FASTER COOKING ESPECIALLY WHEN YOUR MAKING THIS FOR DINNER OR WHEN YOUR HUNGRY.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Our family likes the naan. I used quick yeast and put all ingredients (except butter & garlic (omitted)and put extra 1/2 C water in, it's dry in our location) into KitchenAid; knead for 10 to 15 mins until the dough is smooth and 'stretchy'. I made 18 naan. Roll them thin (7-8 in. diameter). Since I buttered both sides of the dough, no extra oil needed in the pan. Heat non-stick pan medium to low and the dough bubbled nicely (1-2 mins.).

text:
In terms of taste and texture, this naan is pretty much just like something I would get at my favourite Indian restaurant, although it's a bit more dense. I was amazed at how simple it was to make, though it was time-consuming. However, I will have to tweak with it a bit to give it the appearance of authentic naan. I don't have a grill so I tried laying some directly on the grill of the oven and I put a few in the skillet. I don't think I rolled these out flat enough (I don't have a rolling pin) so the ones in the oven were extremely puffy. The ones from the skillet were flatter but weren't as pretty. I think that I will try rolling these out flatter and then baking them on the grill like a pizza.

I chose this naan recipe because I had all the ingredients on hand.  I used regular All Purpose flour instead of bread flour, and they turned out fine.  I cut the recipe in half and prepared the dough in my bread machine. I used a stove-top cast-iron "grill," and made them without garlic and added it to the butter while on the grill. vk3em

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great Recipe. Have made many different naan recipes, and this is by far the best. Time to build a tandoori oven!  A few tips: (1) I used special white flour, which is similar to bread or pizza flour.   (2) I kept the dough moist, because the flour absorbs a lot of water during the rising phase.   (3) I cooked mine over charcoal. I had a charcoal BBQ and hook up a small fan to get it burning really hot. I placed a cast iron grill over it, turned the fan off, put the naan on and then put a large lid over the top. It was the best I could do to simulate a tandoor. Anyway - they cooked in 60 seconds and tasted fantastic - complete with lots of bubbles and a great texture.  Luke

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful. Had this for Indian night and this helped deal with the spicy food. I followed the original recipe but I cooked it in a skillet and I noticed that some of mine had problems rising at first. I solved this by first adding butter for a nice taste then adding the butter side to the skillet, letting it cook slightly, just enough time to butter the other side, then flip it over.  I flip it over a couple of times to help it along, however, burning it actually gave it some really good flavor. Oil helps as well. Next time I'm adding more garlic into the dough because I'm a fan of garlic.

I've never made naan before. I live in Central America and so I wasn't sure I'd be able to find already made naan at the store for our Indian themed party. I decided to try my hand at it with this recipe. It was a huge success!  most of the pieces I ended up with were about the size of the palm of my hand. All the naan I've seen in my favorite Indian restaurants back home was twice that size so if I made this again I would either combine two of the balls before frying or make them twice as big from the start. Also, I don't have a grill so I just fried them on med-high heat in a covered skillet. Watch them closely! I burned a couple... Enjoy! The naan was delicious!

My personal favorite is sprinkling about 2 tsp of curry into the mixture to make a curry naan. The garlic powder is really great to, but I add about 1 tsp more than the recipe calls for.

text:
This bread was amazing.  Easy to make and just impressive!  It is the best bread I've tasted outside of an Indian restaurant.  I was paying $2.79 at a local grocery store for TWO pieces of Naan bread and this recipe yielded at least 15 good sized pieces and they tasted better.  Don't worry if they look floppy on your grill.  Make sure you spray your grill w/nonstick spray, arrange the dough, and you just watch them rise.  It's that simple.

text:
For my first time this came out excellent!!  I always preheat my oven to 200 then turn it off and place the dough with a damp towel over it with the door open to help it rise faster.  Then I tried the suggestions of reviewers and pinched the dough to help it bubble, but forgot to cover while cooking.  The size of the balls is a bit small for my preference and the temp of the stove was a bit high, other than that great recipe!  I added 3 cloves minced garlic to the dough and 2 cloves to the butter.  I keep the dough refrigerated and enjoy them for a few nights!!  Fabulous!!

text:
I just made this on my stove and think that it's just ok.  Though it's nice and soft, it does not taste like naan that I'm used to eating.  I think that the buttering on both sides is a bit excessive (tastes like so much butter) and I think next time I'm just going spray the pan with butter flavored cooking spray and leave it like that.  I'm also going to try adding the baking soda to see if I can get some bubbles next time since that mgiht change it.  I'm going to make some Chicken Tikka Masala tomorrow and eat it with that so hopefully it will taste better that way.  It is very easy to make and so much cheaper than buying the naan in the store.

text:
The flavor of this naan was great, although I couldn't get it to bubble and puff up as much as I wanted to, even after adding 1/2 tsp of baking soda as was suggested. I found that adding a little olive oil to the pan (I don't have a griddle or anything) before cooking each piece of naan helped it to brown nicely and really brought out the flavor (I also brushed each side with butter as the recipe called for). Despite my lack of experience cooking naan, it turned out delicious and I can't wait to try it again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never had naan before and I was preparing an Indian meal so I decided to try this recipe. It was delicious and it tasted quite familiar to me although at first I couldn't figure out what it was. Then I remembered - it tasted very similar to the soft pretzel's from the chain Auntie Ann's. So I decided to use this naan dough recipe for pretzel dough instead from now on. After the the 2nd rising, I rolled out the balls of dough into ropes and shaped them into pretzels. I then dipped them in melted butter and sprinkled on some coarse salt, baked at 425 for about 15 minutes. Yummy! Try it!

Thank you for the great recipe!

text:
I've been experimenting with chapati, rotis and now naan...wow was this recipe awesome!  Last week I purchased some for my curry dinner, and it was good.  This beats the store - bought, hands down!  Yummy.  I have to admit, the flour was a bit much, so I added more water a little at a time till I had a good dough.  Let it rise, made the little balls, andlet them rise.  I rolled it very thin, and sprayed a bit of oil in the frypan, they do cook pretty quickly, and bubble up nicely!  Thanks for posting this recipe!

text:
Very good!  I did add a half tsp of baking soda as someone else suggested, and I'm glad I did--that way I had a little insurance that these would bubble up even if I didn't give them enough time to fully rise.  They were quick to make but still had the flavor of a yeast bread.  I experiemented with cooking methods, and frying in a skillet pan with olive oil WAY beat out the open George Foreman method.  Awesome!

text:
This is the best I have ever tried, but the only change that my Hubby made was
that while grilling the nan he suggested
that I should use Gas Or electris stove and use a Alluminum Frying Pan
instead of Non-Stick version, roll out
the dough pat evenly with your hands into a oblong shape just putting Nan into the pan spread few drops of milk on
top side of the rolled dough evenly spreading allover the naan( make sure
the heat is set to medium heat) place the naan with milk side down over the
pan as naan starts to bubble with few brown spots take the pan from the and
now as naan is firmly stuck to the pan
Flip around the pan and cook the uncooked side that the top side of the 
Naan as bottom isalready cooked on the first stage, finish off with garlic butter before serving.

text:
This naan came out great!  I made a full recipe, divided it into eight big piece, and grilled on a cuisinart griller. Next time I think I'll divide it into six pieces and roll the balls a little thicker. A couple things I would have changed... I thought the naan was way too buttery - after the first two naan that I did, I quit spreading butter on it (although it did taste good, I just like it better with not so much butter). Also, by suggestions from others who tried the recipe, i rolled the naan pretty thin - it was too thin for me. But I like my naan chewy and thick, so I guess it depends on your preference. Mine bubbled a little, but not so much. I also want to try it in a skillet. But the end result still tasted great with some chicken tikki masala and basmati rice!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This Naan was delicious and surprisingly easy to make.  I'm not very experienced with bread making but was very impressed with how this turned out.  I went light on the flour (as advised by other reviewers) and it came out soft and airy.  We didn't eat all of it yesterday, so I saved the rest of the dough in the fridge and we ate it tonight.  Yesterday I grilled it on our indoor grill (DeLonghi), and tonight I did it on a frypan.  It tasted less sweet tonight but was even more airy than yesterday (I'm guessing the yeast consumed the sugar and created more gas).  Oh, and I found it helpful to butter the dough ball before stretching.  This allowed me to get the dough nice and thin before grilling.  Thanks for sharing this fabulous recipe!

Pretty darn good. Didn't taste like our local Indian restaurant's naan, but certainly comparable. I cooked these on our foreman grill. Rather than kneading the garlic into the dough, I sateed the garlic into the melted butter and used the garlic infused butter on the grilled naan. Very tasty. We served this with Aminah A.'s Chickpea Curry...but this could really go with any meal...as a dinner roll replacement.

Great recipe!  I have never eaten naan before, so I didn't even know what it was supposed to taste like, but this recipe was so good!  Like other reviewers, I used my george foreman grill, but next time I will definately try the barbeque grill instead.  They came out pretty good on the G.F. grill, but just took SO LONG to cook! My family loved this bread!  We made this bread with traditional Indian food.  I also used this bread with chicken gyros.  Both times they were great! I made this to take to book club because we had just finished reading the kite runner which takes place in Afghanistan and they ate naan.  I'm not very familiar with Indian food but my friends all liked it served with honey.  My husband thought it tasted like a tortilla.  Seemed very close to the naan I ate in a restaraunt not too many days after.  I think Indian food in general is just not my favorite.

text:
This is a tasty bread but it has more of a pita texture than naan. The naan at my local Indian restaurant is a lot fluffier and soft.  This is more dense and chewy it seems.  I halved the sugar as others mentioned because even after doing so I found it a bit sweet I also didn't add the garlic but made garlic butter to brush over it. Overall it was good and does the trick in a pinch!

text:
This was delicious bread. I had a little trouble rolling out the naan and consequently the pieces were small--however it tasted very similar to naan from a restaurant. I cooked the bread in a heavy fry pan coated with butter at a med-hi heat. They needed only about a min per side and puffed up nicely!! I will be making these again and again...
